DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The elves looked like sailors, Santa's sleigh looked like a string of trucks and Mrs. Claus resembled Dorcas Drake, a woman putting together her 32nd annual Christmas party for needy children. ``Hurry up and take you time,'' Mrs. Drake told Navy volunteers Monday as they left for lunch after a morning of loading the first of 100,000 toys into seven semi-trailer trucks. The toys will be given out Wednesday at Mrs. Drake's all-day fest at the Jacksonville Coliseum. Each child attending the party will receive a bagful of toys from a small army of volunteers. As usual, Mrs. Drake, a former justice of the peace, fretted earlier that she wouldn't collect enough toys for the children. As usual, her worrying has come to another happy end. ``We got enough. I'll just say a quiet `Thank the Lord,''' she said. The warehouse at 1 Santa Claus Lane was a whirlwind of activity as volunteers sorted the toys. Most of the toys were donated by their original owners and those that can't be fixed are discarded. Last year, an estimated 50,000 children attended the party.

Christmas dinner with all the trimmings is no small feat under any circumstances, but John Fegaras is expecting at least 1,800 guests. The open house at one of his restaurants is becoming a Christmas tradition, now six years old, for Fegaras who owns four restaurants in this lakefront community. Three hundred people attended the first dinner, but this year Fegaras expects more than 1,800 people, many of whom have nowhere else to go for Christmas. As in past years, volunteers ranging from Mayor Robert Behler to city bus drivers will help cook and serve the food and transport residents to the restaurant. Behler and his family spent a good part of their Christmas Day helping at the restaurant last year, and he recalls a lot of happy and surprised people. ``I had a hard time convincing a family that drove in from Interstate 94 that there was no charge for dinner,'' Behler said. This year's menu again will feature turkey and ham with all the trimmings. Limited delivery service will be offered to those living within the city who are unable to leave their homes.

Those into the car culture have been busy this Christmas season decking the grills with boughs of jolly. Car wreaths are the seasonal rage, dangling from hood ornaments or tied to the grills of vehicles of every shape and size, from Rolls-Royce, Mercedes-Benz and Range Rover to Chevrolet, Ford and big-rig Peterbilt. ``I figure I spend so much time in my car I should decorate it for Christmas. I think it's great because everybody is so intense right now with he hassle of Christmas,'' said Timi Krissman Freshman. She paid $18.50 for her car's plastic, snow-covered pine ring, complete with fake miniature apples and a red velvet bow. ``The wreath just gives everybody a little lift,'' the 48-year-old real estate agent said. ``It's like (being in) your own personal sleigh,'' Jeep driver Healy Cosay said of the wreath transformation. Jim Morris, who stuck a wreath on his Mercedes, said fellow motorists look and grin, adding: ``People think I'm Santa. They smile and honk and wave.'' Geary's of Beverly Hills has sold more than 2,000 car wreaths this season, said wreath designer Bruce Meyer. ``They're just a very friendly gesture for the season,'' he said. ``I guess you could say we're driving motorists crazy with Christmas cheer.''
